subject: Re: JUnit 3.5 & Ant 1.3
msgSnippet: Yes JUnit is definetly in the classpath. Like I said I use the same  to compile all of my JUnit test with no problem.
messageBody:
Yes JUnit is definetly in the classpath. Like I said I use the same
<classpath refid="test.build.classpath"/> to compile all of my JUnit
test with no problem. But when I use this line in the target that runs
my Junit classes It can not find it. The difference here being that
the javac task def has no problem understanding <classpath
refid="test.build.classpath"/> statement while the junit taskdef seem
to ignore it. I could redefine my classpath using the form that you
used in your example, but that defeats the purpose of me predefining
my test classpath so that I can using over an over again in different
targets.

--- In junit@y..., Marc Pages <marc.pages@m...> wrote:
> I don't know anything about refid but is junit included in the
classpath?
> See the example build file below. (Some of the junit stuff is
derived from
> <http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/library/j-ant/?dwzone=java> )
>
> Marc
>
> ============= build.xml begin
> <?xml version="1.0"?>
>
> <project name="xfiles" default="jar" basedir=".">
>
> <target name="init">
> <property name="name" value="xfiles" />
> <property name="src.dir" value="src" />
> <property name="lib.dir" value="lib" />
> <property name="build.dir" value="build" />
> <property name="dist.dir" value="dist" />
> <property name="build.compiler" value="classic" />
> <property name="junit.dir" value="../junit3.5/junit.jar" />
> </target>
>
> <target name="JUNIT">
> <available classname="junit.framework.TestCase"
> classpath="${junit.dir}/" property="junit.present" />
> </target>
>
> <target name="clean" depends="init">
> <delete dir="${build.dir}" />
> <delete dir="${dist.dir}" />
> </target>
>
> <target name="prepare" depends="init">
> <mkdir dir="${build.dir}" />
> <mkdir dir="${build.dir}/META-INF" />
> <mkdir dir="${dist.dir}" />
> </target>
>
> <target name="compile" depends="prepare,JUNIT">
> <javac srcdir="${src.dir}"
> destdir="${build.dir}/"
> classpath="${lib.dir}/:${junit.dir}/"
> includes="**" />
> </target>
>
> <target name="runtests" depends="compile" if="junit.present">
> <java fork="yes" classname="junit.textui.TestRunner"
> taskname="junit" failonerror="true">
> <arg value="se.offex.jnitnpapi.MarketTest"/>
> <classpath>
> <pathelement location="${build.dir}"/>
> <pathelement path="${junit.dir}/" />
> <pathelement path=""/>
> <pathelement path="${java.class.path}"/>
> </classpath>
> </java>
> </target>
>
> <target name="launchjunit" depends="compile" if="junit.present">
> <java fork="yes" classname="junit.swingui.TestRunner"
> taskname="junit" failonerror="true">
> <classpath>
> <pathelement location="${build.dir}"/>
> <pathelement path="${junit.dir}/" />
> <pathelement path=""/>
> <pathelement path="${java.class.path}"/>
> </classpath>
> </java>
> </target>
>
> <target name="lj" depends="launchjunit"/>
>
> </project>
> ============= build.xml end
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Denny Chambers
> To: junit@y...
> Sent: 2001-03-15 19:34
> Subject: [junit] JUnit 3.5 & Ant 1.3
>
> All,
>
> I am having a problem running my JUnit tests through Ant. I can
build
> them fine using Ant. All of the classes are found properly. However
when
> I try to run the test the JUnit classes can not be found on the
> classpath. I am using the same <classpath
refid="test.build.classpath"
> /> to run the tests that I am using to build. This makes me think
that
> there is a bug with classpath refid in JUnit. I have seen postings
on
> the Ant mailing list where people have had similar problems, but I
> haven't seen any real fixes. Can anyone help?
>
> Thanks,
